rule.name: Process card property pattern
rule.narrative: This rule detects if the Java version is has reached its extended support end of life.

threshold.message: Running on old Java version which has reached end of life. You may consider to upgrade it soon.

rule.name: Process card property number
rule.narrative: This rule detects if the number of CPUs is sufficient.

threshold.message: Production system running with low number of CPUs. You may consider to increase it.
High applicative CPU access, exceeding the system CPU capacity. You may consider to increase it.

rule.name: Process card property pattern
rule.narrative: This rule detects if the Java version is feature version.

threshold.message: Running on a Java features release, not intended for long term production usage. You should consider to upgrade to a long-term support version.

rule.name: Process card property pattern
rule.narrative: This rule detects if the Jeyzer Recorder log level is set to DEBUG.

threshold.message: Jeyer Recorder is logging in DEBUG level and is therefore impacting the application performance. You should revert to INFO in the Jeyzer Recorder logging configuration.

rule.name: Process card property pattern
rule.narrative: This rule detects if the Jeyzer Recorder logging in console is active.

threshold.message: Jeyer Recorder is logging in console : this may affect the application logging. You should disable it in the Jeyzer Recorder logging configuration.

rule.name: Process card property pattern
rule.narrative: This rule detects if the Jeyzer Recorder logging in file is inactive.

threshold.message: Jeyer Recorder is not logging in file. You should activate it in the Jeyzer Recorder logging configuration

rule.name: Process command line parameter absence
rule.narrative: This rule checks if the Xmx parameter is set on the process command line. It is highly recommended having control over the maximum memory limit otherwise the JVM may consume abusively the available system memory.

threshold.message: Maximum Java heap size is not set. Please add the -Xmx<size> to the process startup command line.

rule.name: Process command line parameter pattern
rule.narrative: This rule detects if the JMX remote access is enabled.

rule.name: Process command line parameter pattern
rule.param_display: Java jdwp remote debug access enabled
rule.narrative: This rule detects if the remote debugging is enabled.

threshold.message: Java jdwp remote debug access enabled. This should not happen in production.

rule.name: Process command line parameter pattern
rule.narrative: This rule detects if the Java Flight Recorder is enabled.

rule.name: Process command line parameter pattern
rule.narrative: This rule detects if the Java Flight Recorder is started in profiling mode using the profile.jfc settings file.

threshold.message: Java Flight Recorder is profiling the application and is therefore impacting its performance. Make sure it has been activated on purpose.

rule.name: Process command line property pattern
rule.narrative: This rule checks if the JMX remote authentication is disabled on the command line.

threshold.message: JMX remote authentication is disabled. This security issue should be adressed in a production environment as anybody could take control of the JVM remotely.

rule.name: Process command line property pattern
rule.narrative: This rule checks if the JMX remote SSL is disabled on the command line.

threshold.message: JMX remote SSL is disabled. This JMX connection should be secured in a production environment.

rule.name: Process command line parameter pattern
rule.narrative: This rule detects if the serial garbage collector is enabled on the command line.

threshold.message: The serial garbage collector is used : make sure it is appropriate. It halts any processing while running (stop the world pause) and can therefore impacts the performance. The serial GC applies usually on single processor machines (aka client machines) It should be used on apps which manipulate small amounts of data. Prefer the G1 or PS garbage collectors.

rule.name: Process card property number
rule.narrative: This rule detects if the max file descriptor limit is sufficient.

threshold.message: Unix production system running with a maximmum of 1024 file descriptors (probably the default). You should ask the Unix administrator to increase it if your application does intensive resource access. As reminder, the max file descriptor limit is user based : if all the processes he started consume more than this max limit, the Too Many Open Files error will start to occur in one of them. Check the max limit with ulimit -n
